title: Advanced Pattern Causality: Custom Functions for Tailored Analysis
text: Let’s start creating custom distance metric. example, ’ll implement adaptive distance metric switches Euclidean Manhattan distances based data’s standard deviation. can useful dealing data varying scales distributions. function first checks input matrix, handles NA values replacing mean, decides whether use Euclidean Manhattan distance based standard deviation input data. Finally, ensures distance matrix symmetric zero diagonal.
code: adaptive_distance <- function(x) {   if(!is.matrix(x)) x <- as.matrix(x)   # Ensure no NA values   if(any(is.na(x))) {     x[is.na(x)] <- mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)   }   # Select distance metric based on data distribution   if(sd(x, na.rm = TRUE) > 100) {     x_scaled <- scale(x)     d <- as.matrix(dist(x_scaled, method = "euclidean"))   } else {     d <- as.matrix(dist(x, method = "manhattan"))   }   # Ensure distance matrix is symmetric with zero diagonal   d[is.na(d)] <- 0   d <- (d + t(d))/2   diag(d) <- 0   return(d) }

title: Advanced Pattern Causality: Custom Functions for Tailored Analysis
text: Next, let’s define custom state space reconstruction method. , ’ll implement denoised state space reconstruction using median filter reduce noise time series constructing state space. function applies median filter smooth input time series constructs state space matrix. also handles remaining NA values replacing mean.
code: denoised_state_space <- function(x, E, tau) {   # Use median filtering for denoising   n <- length(x)   x_smooth <- x   window <- 3   for(i in (window+1):(n-window)) {     x_smooth[i] <- median(x[(i-window):(i+window)])   }      # Construct state space   n_out <- length(x_smooth) - (E-1)*tau   mat <- matrix(NA, nrow = n_out, ncol = E)   for(i in 1:E) {     mat[,i] <- x_smooth[1:n_out + (i-1)*tau]   }      # Ensure no NA values   if(any(is.na(mat))) {     mat[is.na(mat)] <- mean(mat, na.rm = TRUE)   }      list(matrix = mat) }
